Active RIPK3 catalyzes the phosphorylation of MLKL, resulting in the formation of MLKL oligomers (most likely trimers or tetramers) that translocate to the plasma membrane, where they bind specific phosphatidylinositol phosphate species by a roll-over mechanism and hence trigger plasma membrane permeabilization [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR435">435</xref>
<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR442">442</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR453">453</xref>].</p><p id="Par59">Although the essential contribution of MLKL to necroptosis has been confirmed by genetic studies [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR435">435</xref>] as well as by pharmacological (i.e., inhibition of MLKL with necrosulfonamide, NSA) interventions [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR442">442</xref>], the precise mechanism through which MLKL executes necroptosis is not completely understood. Recent studies ascribe to the heat shock protein 90 kDa alpha family class A member 1 (HSP90AA1; best known as HSP90) a specific and non-redundant role in MLKL oligomerization and translocation [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR454">454</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR455">455</xref>]. Moreover, it has also been reported that MLKL oligomerization promotes a cascade of intracellular events involving (1) Ca<sup>2+</sup> influx, which is presumably mediated by the MLKL target transient receptor potential cation channel subfamily M member 7 (TRPM7) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR449">449</xref>]; and (2) PS exposure, which seems to be directly operated by MLKL [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR456">456</xref>]. This is followed by the formation of PS-exposing plasma membrane bubbles whose breakdown and release is negatively regulated—in conditions of limited MLKL activation—by the antagonistic activity of the endosomal sorting complex required for transport (ESCRT)-III machinery [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR456">456</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR457">457</xref>]. Once localized at the plasma membrane, MLKL reportedly activates cell-surface proteases of the ADAM family, which can promote the shedding of plasma membrane-associated proteins [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR458">458</xref>], or form Mg<sup>2+</sup> permeant channels [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR459">459</xref>]. Of note, active MLKL also appears to translocate to the nucleus, but the relevance of this phenomenon for necroptosis remains to be investigated [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR460">460</xref>]. Previous data supporting the involvement of PGAM family member 5, serine/threonine protein phosphatase, mitochondrial (PGAM5)- and DRP1-driven mitochondrial fragmentation in necroptosis [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR461">461</xref>] have been conclusively invalidated [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR435">435</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR446">446</xref>
<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR462">462</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR466">466</xref>], confirming that necroptotic signaling can proceed normally independent of mitochondria. Of note, the core components of necroptosis are poorly conserved across the animal kingdom, as some species lack <italic>RIPK3</italic> and/or <italic>MLKL</italic> [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR467">467</xref>]. Moreover, a few non-canonical instances of pseudonecroptotic RCD involving MLKL (but not RIPK3) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR468">468</xref>] or RIPK3 (but not MLKL) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR469">469</xref>] have been described. These observations reinforce the notion that the signaling pathways leading to RCD display a hitherto incompletely understood degree of interconnectivity.</p><p id="Par60">Death receptor (in particular TNFR1) engagement is the trigger for RIPK3 activation best characterized so far. As mentioned above, the biological outcome of TNFR1 signaling spans from cell survival and activation (i.e., cytokine secretion) to multiple subroutines of RCD, depending on a variety of cell-intrinsic (e.g., expression levels of the proteins involved in the process) and cell-extrinsic (e.g., intensity and duration of TNF stimulation) factors [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR283">283</xref>]. In particular, the activation of RIPK3 downstream of TNFR1 ligation relies on the formation of a RIPK1-containing and RIPK3-containing amyloid-like signaling complex commonly known as necrosome [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR436">436</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR470">470</xref>], wherein first RIPK1 and then RIPK3 undergo a series of trans-phosphorylation or auto-phosphorylation events that are required for MLKL recruitment and necroptosis activation [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR437">437</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR438">438</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR442">442</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR471">471</xref>]. Major negative regulators of the necrosome include: (1) STIP1 homology and U-box containing protein 1 (STUB1; also known as CHIP), which promotes RIPK1 and RIPK3 ubiquitination followed by lysosomal degradation [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR472">472</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR473">473</xref>]; (2) A20, which inhibits necrosome assembly by deubiquitinating RIPK3 [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR473">473</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR474">474</xref>]; (3) protein phosphatase, Mg2+/Mn2+ dependent 1B (PPM1B), which prevents MLKL recruitment to the necrosome by dephosphorylating RIPK3 [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR475">475</xref>]; and (4) aurora kinase A (AURKA), which mediates inhibitory function upon physical interaction with RIPK1 and RIPK3 [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR476">476</xref>]. RIPK3 activation also depends on its physical association with a HSP90-containing and cell division cycle 37 (CDC37)-containing co-chaperone complex [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR477">477</xref>]. In addition, the assembly of the necrosome upon TNFR1 stimulation impinges on two conditions: (1) pharmacological or genetic CASP8 inactivation [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR478">478</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR479">479</xref>], and (2) RIPK1 deubiquitination-dependent phosphorylation (at least in some settings), which can be favored by exogenously provided SMAC mimetics, ensuring the release of RIPK1 from complex I (see above) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR334">334</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR335">335</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR480">480</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR481">481</xref>].</p><p id="Par61">As for the first condition, compelling experimental findings demonstrate that the concerted activity of CASP8, FADD, and c-FLIP<sub>L</sub> tonically inhibits necroptosis [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR432">432</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR466">466</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR478">478</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR479">479</xref>
<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR482">482</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR484">484</xref>]. Thus, the embryonic lethality imposed on mice by the loss of <italic>Casp8</italic> or <italic>Fadd</italic> can be rescued by concurrent ablation of <italic>Ripk3</italic> or <italic>Mlkl</italic>, even though these double knockout animals generally display lymphoproliferative and/or systemic autoimmune disorders as adults [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR432">432</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR466">466</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR484">484</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR485">485</xref>]. Of note, <italic>Cflar</italic><sup><italic>−/−</italic></sup> mice require the concomitant knockout of <italic>Ripk3</italic> and <italic>Fadd</italic> to develop into adulthood, which underscores the inhibitory role of c-FLIP in both necroptosis and extrinsic apoptosis reported above [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR483">483</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR486">486</xref>]. Along similar lines, the concurrent deletion of <italic>Ripk3</italic> averts perturbations of cutaneous and intestinal homeostasis imposed by the tissue-specific ablation of <italic>Fadd</italic> or <italic>Casp8</italic> [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR483">483</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR487">487</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR488">488</xref>]. Moreover, the proliferative defects of <italic>Casp8</italic><sup><italic>−/−</italic></sup> or <italic>Fadd</italic><sup><italic>−/−</italic></sup> T cells can be rescued by the administration of the RIPK1 inhibitor Nec-1 or the concomitant ablation of <italic>Ripk3</italic> [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR489">489</xref>]. Necroptosis is also tonically inhibited by c-IAPs, owing to their ability to ubiquitinate RIPK1 [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR490">490</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR493">493</xref>]. Accordingly, necroptosis relies on the deubiquitinating activity of CYLD [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR338">338</xref>], which is also a proteolytic target of CASP8 [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR494">494</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR496">496</xref>]. Finally, some components of the TNFR1 signaling cascade reportedly regulate necroptosis either in a negative manner, by catalyzing the inhibitory phosphorylation of RIPK1 (e.g., the IKK complex and MK2) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR335">335</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR336">336</xref>] and constitutively interacting with (and thus preventing the activation of) MLKL (e.g., TRAF2) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR497">497</xref>], or in a positive manner, by favoring the activating phosphorylation of RIPK1 or RIPK3 upon prolonged activation (e.g., TAK1) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR334">334</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR498">498</xref>]. In this context, CYLD also contributes to necroptosis by deubiquitinating—and hence suppressing the anti-necroptotic activity of—TRAF2 [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR497">497</xref>].</p><p id="Par62">That said, mounting evidence indicates that necroptosis driven by several stimuli—in some circumstances even TNFR1 activation—does not necessarily rely on RIPK1. Thus, in contrast to <italic>Ripk3</italic><sup><italic>−/−</italic></sup> mice that are viable and fertile, the <italic>Ripk1</italic><sup><italic>−/−</italic></sup> genotype causes perinatal lethality [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR482">482</xref>], which cannot be prevented by the ablation of <italic>Ripk3</italic>, <italic>Casp8</italic>, or <italic>Fadd</italic> alone, but can be rescued by the co-deletion of <italic>Ripk3</italic> and C<italic>asp8</italic>, <italic>Fadd</italic> or <italic>Tnfrsf1a</italic> [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR482">482</xref>
<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR499">499</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR501">501</xref>]. Moreover, <italic>Ripk1</italic><sup><italic>−/−</italic></sup> cells display increased sensitivity to necroptosis and/or extrinsic apoptosis induced by a set of innate immune stimuli [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR499">499</xref>]. Conditional knockout mouse models demonstrate the key role of RIPK1 for the preservation of intestinal and cutaneous homeostasis and survival [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR502">502</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR503">503</xref>]. In particular, mice lacking <italic>Ripk1</italic> in intestinal epithelial cells display increased rates of spontaneous CASP8-driven apoptosis and develop severe inflammatory lesions leading to premature death, a detrimental phenotype that can be prevented by co-deleting <italic>Fadd</italic> or (to a lesser degree) <italic>Tnfrsf1a</italic> [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR502">502</xref>]. Likewise, the absence of <italic>Ripk1</italic> from keratinocytes promotes spontaneous necroptosis and consequent cutaneous inflammation, which can be prevented by the co-deletion of <italic>Ripk3</italic>, <italic>Mlkl</italic>, or <italic>Zbp1</italic> but not <italic>Fadd</italic> [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR440">440</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR502">502</xref>]. Collectively, these results suggest that (at least in some settings) RIPK1 can inhibit (rather than activate) RIPK3-dependent necroptosis and/or CASP8-dependent extrinsic apoptosis [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR504">504</xref>]. At least in some settings, this reflects the major role of RIPK1 in NF-κB activation [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR505">505</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR507">507</xref>].</p><p id="Par63">Intriguingly, the pro-survival role of RIPK1 in development seems to be independent of both its kinase activity and RIPK3 binding, as demonstrated by the fact that mice genetically engineered to express a kinase-dead variant of RIPK1 (e.g., RIPK1<sup>K45A</sup>) are viable and fertile [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR447">447</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR499">499</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR508">508</xref>]. Moreover, it has recently been reported that the autophagic receptor optineurin (OPTN) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR509">509</xref>] actively regulates the proteasomal turnover of RIPK1, as the loss of OPTN induces axonal degeneration via RIPK1-dependent necroptosis [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR510">510</xref>]. Inhibitor of nuclear factor kappa B kinase subunit gamma (IKBKG; best known as NEMO) also prevents RIPK1-driven intestinal inflammation and epithelial cell death, although the underlying molecular mechanisms remain poorly understood [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR511">511</xref>] Finally, when catalytically inactive or inhibited by specific pharmacological agents such as Nec-1, RIPK1 (and, at least under certain circumstances, RIPK3) reportedly contributes to specific forms of CASP8-dependent apoptosis (see above) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR335">335</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR336">336</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR446">446</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR447">447</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR481">481</xref>
<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR512">512</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR516">516</xref>]. The current view ascribes the opposing roles of RIPK1 (and—at least in part—RIPK3) in promoting or inhibiting RCD to its kinase-dependent vs. kinase-independent (i.e., scaffolding) functions, respectively [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR4">4</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR517">517</xref>].</p><p id="Par64">As mentioned above, RIPK3 can be activated by proteins involved in innate immunity to invading pathogens including TRIF and ZBP1 [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR428">428</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR439">439</xref>]. Thus, in the absence of CASP8 activity, stimulation of TLR3 or TLR4 by their respective ligands promotes necroptosis upon the interaction between TRIF and RIPK3 and the consequent activation of MLKL [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR428">428</xref>]. Accordingly, the synthetic TLR3 ligand polyinosinic-polycytidylic acid (polyI:C) or the co-administration of low-dose LPS and the caspase inhibitor Z-VAD-fmk trigger necroptosis in dendritic cells (DCs) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR518">518</xref>] or microglial cells [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR519">519</xref>], respectively. In this context, IFN alpha and beta receptor subunit 1 (IFNAR1) and IFN gamma receptor 1 (IFNGR1) also appear to have pro-necroptotic functions [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR520">520</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR523">523</xref>]. Thus, <italic>Ifnar1</italic><sup><italic>−/−</italic></sup> macrophages are resistant to RCD induced by LPS or polyI:C in the context of caspase inhibition, which would otherwise trigger a necroptotic process relying on TRIF and tonic IFN-stimulated gene factor 3 (ISGF3) signaling [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR523">523</xref>]. Genetic studies demonstrate that the lethality imposed to mice by the <italic>Ripk1</italic><sup><italic>−/−</italic></sup><italic>Tnfrsf1a</italic><sup><italic>−/−</italic></sup> genotype is delayed (but not prevented) by the co-deletion of <italic>Ticam1</italic> or <italic>Ifnar1</italic> [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR482">482</xref>]. Moreover, <italic>Ripk1</italic><sup><italic>−/−</italic></sup> cells are more sensitive to necroptosis induced by polyI:C or type I IFN [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR482">482</xref>]. However, <italic>Tnfrsf1a</italic><sup><italic>−/−</italic></sup><italic>Ripk1</italic><sup><italic>−/−</italic></sup><italic>Ripk3</italic><sup><italic>−/−</italic></sup> mice develop into adulthood, suggesting the existence of additional RIPK3 activators [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR482">482</xref>].</p><p id="Par65">Recently, the mechanism underlying ZBP1-mediated necroptosis and its regulation by RIPK1 has been elucidated [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR440">440</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR441">441</xref>]. ZBP1 acts at the initial steps of necroptosis by mediating the sequential activation of RIPK3 and MLKL. Moreover, mice expressing a variant of RIPK1 mutated in the RHIM domain die perinatally, a phenotype that can be rescued by concurrent <italic>Ripk3</italic>, <italic>Mlkl</italic>, or <italic>Zbp1</italic> (but not <italic>Ticam1</italic>) deletion, as well as by the knock-in of catalytically inactive RIPK3 or RIPK3 mutated in the RHIM domain [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR440">440</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR441">441</xref>]. This suggests that the RHIM of RIPK1 acts as an inhibitor of ZBP1-driven necroptosis, most likely because it prevents the interaction between ZBP1 and RIPK3. Further investigation is required to clarify the mechanisms of ZBP1 activation in this context and its relevance for development and homeostatic tissue regulation. Importantly, multiple components of the molecular machinery for necroptosis—including ZBP1, RIPK3, MLKL, and TNFR1 (mainly via NF-κB)—impinge on the control of the so-called “inflammasome”, a supramolecular platform for the activation of CASP1 and consequent secretion of mature interleukin 1 beta (IL1B; best known as IL-1β) and IL18 [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR524">524</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR529">529</xref>]. Discussing in detail these links—which exemplify the complex interconnection between RCD signaling and inflammatory responses—goes beyond the scope of this review [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR4">4</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR8">8</xref>
<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR530">530</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR532">532</xref>].</p><p id="Par66">In summary, we propose to define necroptosis as a type of RCD triggered by perturbations of extracellular or intracellular homeostasis that critically depends on MLKL, RIPK3, and (at least in some settings) on the kinase activity of RIPK1 (Box <xref ref-type="sec" rid="FPar1">1</xref>).</p></sec><sec id="Sec6"><title>Ferroptosis</title><p id="Par67">Ferroptosis is a form of RCD initiated by specific perturbations of the intracellular microenvironment, notably severe lipid peroxidation, which relies on ROS generation and iron availability [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR533">533</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR536">536</xref>]. The molecular mechanisms precipitating ferroptosis have begun to emerge [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR534">534</xref>], and (so far) ferroptotic RCD has been linked to toxic lipid peroxide accrual [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR537">537</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR538">538</xref>]. Ferroptosis occurs independently of caspases, necrosome components and CYPD, and the molecular machinery for autophagy [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR539">539</xref>], manifests with a necrotic morphotype (with a predominance of mitochondrial alterations encompassing shrinkage, an electron-dense ultrastructure, reduced/disappeared cristae, and ruptured OMM) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR374">374</xref>], and is potentially associated with a consistent release of immunostimulatory DAMPs [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR540">540</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR541">541</xref>]. Interestingly, BCL2 has been suggested to limit the physiological demise of neuron progenitors failing to differentiate via a mechanism that (1) does not depend on BAX and caspases, and (2) can be suppressed by ferroptosis inhibitors [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR542">542</xref>]. The actual implication of BCL2 in the regulation of ferroptosis, however, remains to be firmly established.</p><p id="Par68">Some of the molecular circuitries regulating the initial steps of ferroptosis have been recently unveiled by employing (1) specific ferroptosis-inducing agents, including erastin [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR543">543</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR544">544</xref>], RSL3 [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR543">543</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR544">544</xref>], and FIN56 [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR545">545</xref>]; and (2) specific ferroptosis-inhibiting agents, including ferrostatins [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR539">539</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR546">546</xref>] and liproxstatins [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR547">547</xref>]. In particular, the reduced glutathione (GSH)-dependent enzyme glutathione peroxidase 4 (GPX4)—which is directly targeted by RSL3—has emerged as the main endogenous inhibitor of ferroptosis by virtue of its ability to limit lipid peroxidation by catalyzing the GSH-dependent reduction of lipid hydroperoxides to lipid alcohols [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR547">547</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR550">550</xref>]. In line with this notion, erastin triggers ferroptosis by (indirectly) affecting the catalytic cycle of GPX4 via a mechanism that involves the inhibition of the cystine/glutamate antiporter system x<sub>c</sub><sup>−</sup> and consequent decrease in intracellular cysteine (which derives from cystine reduction in the cytoplasm) and GSH (which is synthesized from cysteine) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR539">539</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR548">548</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR549">549</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR551">551</xref>]. Accordingly, depleting GSH with <italic>L</italic>-buthionine sulfoximine (BSO)—an inhibitor of the glutamate–cysteine ligase complex—can induce ferroptotic RCD (at least in some cases) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR547">547</xref>]. Moreover, the toxicity of high extracellular glutamate may depend (at least in part) on the activation of ferroptosis through cysteine imbalance [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR534">534</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR538">538</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR552">552</xref>]. Of relevance for cancer therapy, the pronounced addiction of triple-negative breast carcinoma to glutamine relates (at least in part) to its ability to drive cystine uptake via x<sub>c</sub><sup>−</sup>, implying that x<sub>c</sub><sup>−</sup> may constitute a therapeutic target in this setting [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR553">553</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR554">554</xref>]. Moreover, the FDA-approved tyrosine kinase inhibitor sorafenib can trigger ferroptosis in distinct cellular models by depleting GSH upon system x<sub>c</sub><sup>−</sup> inhibition [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR551">551</xref>
<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR555">555</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR557">557</xref>], while altretamine (an FDA-approved alkylating agent) has been recently identified as a potential inhibitor of GPX4 by a regulatory network genome-wide system strategy [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR558">558</xref>]. Thus, the antineoplastic effects of sorafenib and altretamine may partially stem from the activation of ferroptosis. Notably, the demise of neurons caused by inhibition of x<sub>c</sub><sup>−</sup> was initially referred to as oxytosis, oxidative glutamate toxicity, or excitotoxicity, and was linked to alterations in intracellular Ca<sup>2+</sup> homeostasis [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR559">559</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR561">561</xref>]. It remains unclear to which extent oxytosis can be mechanistically discriminated from ferroptosis and MPT-driven necrosis in diverse cellular contexts.</p><p id="Par69">Recent evidence indicates that ferroptosis involves the preferential oxidation of specific phosphatidylethanolamine-containing polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) such as arachidonic and adrenic acid [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR562">562</xref>]. In line with a critical requirement for oxidizable PUFAs, genetic and/or pharmacological inhibition of acyl-CoA synthetase long chain family member 4 (ACSL4) and lysophosphatidylcholine acyltransferase 3 (LPCAT3), both of which are involved in the incorporation of long PUFAs into cellular membranes, protects cells against ferroptosis (at least in some settings) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR562">562</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR565">565</xref>]. Lipid hydroperoxides can be formed by autoxidation or via enzymatic reactions catalyzed by lipoxygenases (LOXs) or cyclooxygenases (COXs). In the context of ferroptosis, PUFA peroxidation seems to be mainly regulated by the mutually antagonistic activity of LOXs (which directly catalyze lipid peroxidation) and GPX4 (which indirectly inhibits it) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR550">550</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR566">566</xref>]. Although arachidonate 15-lipoxygenase (ALOX15) was initially thought to play a major role in this setting, the deletion of <italic>Alox15</italic> fails to rescue the renal phenotype imposed by the <italic>Gpx4</italic><sup><italic>−/−</italic></sup> genotype (see below) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR547">547</xref>], suggesting that multiple LOXs are involved in PUFA peroxidation and consequent ferroptosis in some mouse tissues. Accordingly, oxidized PUFAs accumulate upon GPX4 inactivation and this can result in PUFA fragmentation and ferroptosis [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR539">539</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR547">547</xref>]. This lethal cascade can be prevented by antioxidant agents such as ferrostatin-1 (Fer-1), liproxstatin-1 (Lip-1) as well as by vitamin E, coenzyme Q<sub>10</sub> and their analogs, all of which efficiently limit lipid peroxidation by operating as ROS scavengers [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR539">539</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR547">547</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR550">550</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR562">562</xref>
<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR567">567</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR569">569</xref>]. Of note, the catalytic sites of LOXs contain di-iron centers [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR570">570</xref>]. This may explain: (1) the ferroptosis-inhibiting effect of iron depletion by either chelators [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR539">539</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR543">543</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR548">548</xref>] or phosphorylase kinase catalytic subunit gamma 2 (<italic>PHKG2</italic>) knockdown [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR566">566</xref>], and (2) the ferroptosis-promoting effect of increased intracellular iron availability consequent to import by the circulating iron carrier transferrin (TF) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR571">571</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR572">572</xref>], degradation of ferritin (a cellular iron storage complex) by a specific autophagic mechanism known as ferritinophagy [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR573">573</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR574">574</xref>], disruption of iron homeostasis induced by nanoparticles [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR541">541</xref>], or administration of a bioavailable iron form [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR575">575</xref>]. Alternatively, the critical dependency of ferroptosis on iron can also be ascribed to the ability of this heavy metal to promote non-enzymatic lipid oxidation via lysosomal Fenton reactions [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR538">538</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR572">572</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR576">576</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR577">577</xref>].</p><p id="Par70">Additional ferroptosis regulators described so far include: (1) the mevalonate pathway component farnesyl-diphosphate farnesyltransferase 1 (FDFT1; best known as SQS) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR545">545</xref>]; (2) the transsulfuration pathway enzyme cysteinyl-tRNA synthetase (CARS) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR578">578</xref>]; (3) heat shock protein family B (small) member 1 (HSPB1; best known as HSP27) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR579">579</xref>] and heat shock protein family A (Hsp70) member 5 (HSPA5) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR580">580</xref>]; (4) glutaminolysis [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR571">571</xref>]; (5) components of the MAPK signaling pathway [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR539">539</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR581">581</xref>]; (6) the nuclear factor, erythroid 2 like 2 (NFE2L2; best known NRF2) signaling pathway [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR582">582</xref>]; (7) metallothionein 1G (MT1G) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR583">583</xref>]; (8) dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR584">584</xref>]; (9) Fanconi anemia complementation group D2 (FANCD2) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR585">585</xref>]; and (10) CDGSH iron sulfur domain 1 (CISD1; also known as mitoNEET) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR586">586</xref>]. Elucidating the precise role of these proteins or signaling pathways in ferroptosis requires further investigation.</p><p id="Par71">Accumulating evidence demonstrates that the pro-survival functions of GPX4 contribute to development and homeostatic tissue maintenance. <italic>Gpx4</italic><sup><italic>−/−</italic></sup> mice display embryonic lethality with complete penetrance [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR547">547</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR550">550</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR587">587</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR588">588</xref>]. Moreover, the inducible or tissue-specific ablation of <italic>Gpx4</italic> in mice provokes a variety of pathological conditions, including acute renal or hepatic injury [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR547">547</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR563">563</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR589">589</xref>], neurodegeneration [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR550">550</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR590">590</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR591">591</xref>], and defective immunity to infection [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR567">567</xref>], all of which can be prevented or mitigated by ferroptosis-inhibiting strategies. A similar protective effect is observed in GPX4-independent models of renal ischemic or toxic injury [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR540">540</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR592">592</xref>], Parkinson disease [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR593">593</xref>], and other human pathologies [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR594">594</xref>]. Moreover, ferroptosis appears to operate as a bona fide oncosuppressive mechanism [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR548">548</xref>
<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR595">595</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR598">598</xref>]. It has been proposed—but remains to be formally established—that part of the multipronged oncosuppressor functions of p53 may derive from the transcriptional downregulation of components of system x<sub>c</sub><sup>−</sup>, which would impinge on specific post-translational modifications of p53 [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR596">596</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR598">598</xref>]. Accordingly, the ability of ATF4 to upregulate system x<sub>c</sub><sup>−</sup> and stabilize GPX4 (upon <italic>HSPA5</italic> transactivation) is causally involved in some models of oncogenesis and chemoresistance to ferroptosis induction [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR580">580</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR599">599</xref>]. Along similar lines, parts of the oncogenic effects of NRF2 activation driven by cancer-associated mutations in kelch like ECH associated protein 1 (<italic>KEAP1</italic>) may derive from the upregulation of system x<sub>c</sub><sup>−</sup> [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR582">582</xref>]. Conversely, p53 appears to inhibit ferroptosis in colorectal cancer cells, at least in part by inhibiting DPP4 activity in a transcription-independent manner [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR584">584</xref>]. Of note, malignant cells with a mesenchymal phenotype (which are generally more resistant to treatment) reportedly acquire an accrued dependency on GPX4 activity, which can be exploited therapeutically [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR600">600</xref>]. Recently, a ferroptosis-like RCD subroutine has been described in plants responding to moderate heat stress, supporting some degree of evolutionary conservation and the relevance of ferroptosis for organismal homeostasis [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR601">601</xref>]. In this context, it is worth noting that the pharmacological inhibition of ferroptosis, but not necroptosis or apoptosis, protects tissues such as renal tubules from ischemia/reperfusion injury [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR540">540</xref>]. The precise role of ferroptosis in development and tissue homeostasis, however, remains to be fully elucidated.</p><p id="Par72">We propose to define ferroptosis as a form of RCD initiated by oxidative perturbations of the intracellular microenvironment that is under constitutive control by GPX4 and can be inhibited by iron chelators and lipophilic antioxidants (Box <xref ref-type="sec" rid="FPar1">1</xref>).</p></sec><sec id="Sec7"><title>Pyroptosis</title><p id="Par73">Pyroptosis is a form of RCD triggered by perturbations of extracellular or intracellular homeostasis related to innate immunity (e.g., pathogen invasion) manifesting with specific morphological feature [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR602">602</xref>]. These include a peculiar form of chromatin condensation that differs from its apoptotic counterpart, as well as cellular swelling culminating with plasma membrane permeabilization [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR602">602</xref>]. The term pyroptosis was originally coined by Cookson and Brennan to define a particular type of RCD partially resembling apoptosis but dependent on inflammatory CASP1 (and hence linked to pyrexia) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR603">603</xref>], and several names including pyronecrosis have been introduced since to define partially related processes [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR604">604</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR605">605</xref>]. Initially, pyroptosis was thought to be relevant only for the demise of monocytes or macrophages undergoing canonical CASP1 activation [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR606">606</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR607">607</xref>]. However, recent findings indicate that pyroptosis (1) can be also driven by several other caspases including CASP3 [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR608">608</xref>], (2) can also occur in cell types other than cells from the monocytic lineage [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR609">609</xref>], (3) has a major role in innate immunity against intracellular pathogens [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR602">602</xref>], and (4) is etiologically involved in pathological conditions such as lethal septic shock (at least as induced by LPS) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR610">610</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR611">611</xref>].</p><p id="Par74">At a molecular level, pyroptosis generally relies on the activation of one or more caspases, including CASP1, CASP3, murine CASP11, and its human homologs CASP4 and CASP5, depending on the initiating stimulus [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR612">612</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR613">613</xref>]. Thus, pyroptosis is often (if not always) associated with IL-1β and IL18 secretion, and hence mediates robust pro-inflammatory effects [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR614">614</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR615">615</xref>]. A large body of evidence indicates that cytosolic LPS from invading Gram-negative bacteria is a major trigger of pyroptosis. In particular, it has been shown that CASP11 is responsible for the CASP1-independent death of macrophages responding to Gram-negative bacterial infection [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR616">616</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR619">619</xref>]. Moreover, <italic>Casp11</italic> deletion protects mice against a challenge with cytosol-invasive bacteria [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR612">612</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR620">620</xref>], as well as against systemic LPS administration and consequent pyroptosis-dependent endotoxic shock [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR616">616</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR621">621</xref>]. Further experimental observations confirmed that CASP11, CASP4, and CASP5 trigger pyroptosis upon sensing cytosolic LPS [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR609">609</xref>
<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR622">622</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR624">624</xref>], in monocytes as well as in other cell types [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR609">609</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR625">625</xref>]. In particular, LPS-induced pyroptosis involves the physical interaction of LPS (or its lipid moiety) with the CARD domain of CASP11, CASP4, or CASP5, a highly specific binding resulting in caspase oligomerization and consequent activation [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR609">609</xref>]. Thus, CASP11, CASP4, and CASP5 act as bona fide PRRs for cytosolic LPS. Once activated beyond a specific threshold, inflammatory caspases precipitate pyroptosis by catalyzing the proteolytic cleavage of GSDMD [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR621">621</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR626">626</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR627">627</xref>]. However, at least in some cell types including DCs, CASP11 activation can drive IL-1β secretion in the absence of cell death [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR628">628</xref>].</p><p id="Par75">In line with a critical role of GSDMD, <italic>Gsdmd</italic><sup><italic>−/−</italic></sup> macrophages are resistant to LPS-induced and Gram-negative bacteria-induced pyroptosis, and <italic>Gsdmd</italic><sup><italic>−/−</italic></sup> mice survive doses of LPS that induce lethal endotoxic shock in their wild-type counterparts [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR621">621</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR626">626</xref>]. Recent findings demonstrate that GSDMD is constitutionally auto-inhibited by the binding of its C-terminal repressor domain (GSDMD-C, or RD) to its N-terminal pore-forming domain (GSDMD-N, or PFD). On pyroptosis induction, inflammatory caspases relieve this inhibition by catalyzing the proteolytic cleavage of the interdomain loop, which promotes the release of the pyroptotic inducer GSDMD-N [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR621">621</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR629">629</xref>]. Cleaved GSDMD-N acquires the ability to translocate to the inner leaflet of the plasma membrane (or the bacterial plasma membrane), where it binds with high specificity to selected phosphoinositides (or cardiolipin) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR629">629</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR630">630</xref>]. Membrane targeting enables GSDMD-N oligomerization, generating a pore that is responsible for rapid plasma membrane permeabilization [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR629">629</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR633">633</xref>]. Of note, the GSDMD pore has recently been characterized at the ultrastructural level, consisting of 16 symmetric protomers with an inner diameter of ~10–14 nm [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR629">629</xref>].</p><p id="Par76">Active CASP1 can also cleave GSDMD, suggesting that microbe-associated molecular patterns (MAMPs) other than cytosolic LPS as well as DAMPs usually stimulating canonical inflammasome signaling can initiate pyroptosis [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR626">626</xref>
<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR634">634</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR636">636</xref>]. CASP1-driven pyroptosis limits the spreading of intracellular bacteria by (1) killing the host cell [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR637">637</xref>], and (2) generating so-called “pore-induced intracellular traps (PITs)”, which essentially are dead macrophages that can be efficiently disposed of (together with the living bacteria they trap) by efferocytosis [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR638">638</xref>]. Supporting the critical role of CASP1-driven pyroptosis for innate immune responses against invading bacteria, <italic>Nlrc4</italic><sup><italic>−/−</italic></sup> mice (which are unable to normally activate CASP1) succumb to low amounts of otherwise innocuous environmental opportunists (e.g., <italic>Chromobacterium violaceum</italic>) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR639">639</xref>]. Instances of CASP1-dependent but GSDMD-independent RCD have also been reported, including the demise of macrophages experiencing prolonged canonical inflammasome activation [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR621">621</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR636">636</xref>]. Of note, additional substrates of inflammatory caspases have been hypothesized to participate in pyroptosis. Experiments with knockout mice suggest that the endotoxic shock caused by systemic LPS administration involves the CASP11-dependent cleavage not only of GSDMD, but also of pannexin 1 (PANX1) channels, leading to ATP release in the extracellular space and consequent activation of purinergic receptor P2X 7 (P2RX7), which further impinges on the collapse of ionic gradients and inflammasome signaling [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR640">640</xref>]. Most likely, however, these findings reflect the presence of an inactivating passenger mutation in <italic>Casp11</italic> specifically affecting transgenic mice generated from 129/Sv-derived embryonic stem cells [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR641">641</xref>]. Moreover, CASP1 has been proposed to drive pyroptosis by causing mitochondrial damage upon cleavage of parkin RBR E3 ubiquitin protein ligase (PRKN; best known as PARKIN) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR642">642</xref>]. However, contrasting observations have been reported [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR528">528</xref>], and the actual pathophysiological relevance of the latter mechanism remains to be established.</p><p id="Par77">Accumulating evidence indicates that the (shared) N-terminal domains of other members of the gasdermin family, including GSDMA, GSDMB, GSDMC, GSDME/DFNA5, and GSDMA3 (which is encoded by the mouse—but not the human—genome), resemble those of GSDMD as they display pore-forming and pyroptotic activity [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR39">39</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR613">613</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR626">626</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR629">629</xref>]. Although the mechanisms underlying the activation of GSDMA remain unknown, two recent studies demonstrate the existence of an instance of pyroptotic RCD dependent on GSDME-N/DFNA5-N that can be elicited by multiple challenges, including TNF, various DNA-damaging chemotherapeutic agents, and/or infection with the vesicular stomatitis virus [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR39">39</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR613">613</xref>]. In this setting, CASP3 is responsible for the proteolytic cleavage of GSDME/DFNA5, which precipitates in pyroptosis rather than apoptosis [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR39">39</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR613">613</xref>]. As GSDME/DFNA5 is often silenced in malignant cells but expressed by their normal counterparts, the activation of GSDME/DFNA5 by CASP3 contributes to the side effects of multiple chemotherapeutic agents, at least in mice [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR613">613</xref>]. Interestingly, GSDME/DFNA5 has also been involved in the acquisition of a necrotic phenotype by cells undergoing CASP3-driven apoptosis in vitro (in the absence of proficient phagocytosis) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR39">39</xref>], further demonstrating the elevated degree of interconnectivity that exists between distinct types of RCD. The identification of multiple gasdermin family members as key factors in the late steps of pyroptosis, as well as the characterization of CASP3 as an activator of GSDME/DFNA5, expanded the relevance of this RCD form (and its definition, see below) well beyond inflammatory settings [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR613">613</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR626">626</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR629">629</xref>]. Of note, type I IFN and IFN gamma (IFNG) also contribute to pyroptosis by promoting: (1) the transactivation of <italic>CASP11</italic>, through an IFNAR1-dependent or IFNGR1-dependent mechanism initiated by TLR4 or IL18 signaling [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR620">620</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR643">643</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR644">644</xref>]; (2) TLR7, cyclic GMP-AMP synthase (CGAS), transmembrane protein 173 (TMEM173; best known as STING), DExD/H-box helicase 58 (DDX58; best known as RIG-I), or mitochondrial antiviral signaling protein (MAVS) signaling upon bacterial or viral infection [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR525">525</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR645">645</xref>]; or (3) the expression of guanylate-binding proteins and an IFN-inducible GTPase commonly known as IRGB10 (official name Gm12250), which increase cytosolic LPS levels by mediating the lysis of vacuoles containing Gram-negative bacteria [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR646">646</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR648">648</xref>].</p><p id="Par78">Further underscoring the complexity of the interaction between inflammation and pyroptosis [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR649">649</xref>], CASP11 can also be upregulated by a complement cascade dependent on carboxypeptidase B1 (CPB1) acting downstream of TLR4 and IFNAR1 activation [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR650">650</xref>]. Moreover, cytosolic LPS promotes the secretion of inflammatory cytokines by a mechanism involving CASP11 activation, followed by GSDMD cleavage, loss of K<sup>+</sup> ions, and consequent activation of CASP1 by the NLR family pyrin domain containing 3 (NLRP3) inflammasome, in vitro (but perhaps not in vivo) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR616">616</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR620">620</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR621">621</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR626">626</xref>
<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR651">651</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR655">655</xref>].</p><p id="Par79">We propose to define pyroptosis as a form of RCD that critically depends on the formation of plasma membrane pores by members of the gasdermin protein family, often (but not always) as a consequence of inflammatory caspase activation. The NCCD discourages the use of alternative terms including pyronecrosis (Box <xref ref-type="sec" rid="FPar1">1</xref>).</p></sec><sec id="Sec8"><title>Parthanatos</title><p id="Par80">Parthanatos is a form of RCD driven by the hyperactivation of a specific component of the DNA damage response (DDR) machinery, namely, poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase 1 (PARP1). Notably, parthanatos appears to occur not only as a consequence of severe/prolonged alkylating DNA damage, but also in response to oxidative stress, hypoxia, hypoglycemia, or inflammatory cues [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR656">656</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR658">658</xref>]. In this context, reactive nitrogen species (RNS) including NO stand out as major triggers for PARP1 hyperactivation, especially in neurons [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR659">659</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR661">661</xref>]. PARP1 hyperactivation mediates cytotoxic effects as it causes (1) NAD<sup>+</sup> and ATP depletion, which ultimately results in a bioenergetic and redox collapse, and (2) the accumulation of poly(ADP-ribose) polymers and poly(ADP-ribosyl)ated proteins at mitochondria, ultimately causing Δψ<sub>m</sub> dissipation and MOMP [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR656">656</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR657">657</xref>
<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR662">662</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR665">665</xref>].</p><p id="Par81">One of the key processes of parthanatos is the binding of poly(ADP-ribose) polymers to apoptosis inducing factor mitochondria associated 1 (AIFM1; best known as AIF). This promotes the release of AIF into the cytosol and its translocation into the nucleus, where it mediates large-scale DNA fragmentation and chromatin condensation [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR656">656</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR658">658</xref>
<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR664">664</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR667">667</xref>]. Further corroborating a key role for poly(ADP-ribosyl)ation in parthanatos, the poly(ADP-ribose)-degrading protein ADP-ribosylhydrolase like 2 (ADPRHL2; also known as ARH3) and the poly(ADP-ribose)-binding protein ring finger protein 146 (RNF146; best known as IDUNA) prevent AIF release and consequent RCD as they decrease poly(ADP-ribose) levels and availability, respectively [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR662">662</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR668">668</xref>]. Moreover, specific pharmacological inhibitors of PARP1 efficiently delay parthanatos in multiple cell types, in vitro and in vivo [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR1">1</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR669">669</xref>]. Parthanatotic DNA fragmentation occurs independently of apoptotic caspases and endonuclease G (ENDOG) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR670">670</xref>], a mitochondrial nuclease that precipitates RCD by a mechanism involving its release followed by translocation to the nucleus (at least in <italic>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</italic>, <italic>Caenorhabditis elegans,</italic> and <italic>Drosophila melanogaster</italic>) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR671">671</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR674">674</xref>]. Indeed, the actual contribution of ENDOG to RCD in mammals [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR675">675</xref>] has been questioned by the generation of <italic>Endog</italic><sup><italic>−/−</italic></sup> mice, whose cells display normal sensitivity to multiple lethal triggers [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR676">676</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR677">677</xref>]. That said, it seems that the catalytic activity of CPS-6 (the homolog of ENDOG in <italic>C. elegans</italic>) is boosted upon interaction with WAH-1 (the worm homolog of AIF) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR678">678</xref>].</p><p id="Par82">Macrophage migration inhibitory factor (MIF) has emerged as the main nuclease precipitating parthanatos in a recent screening for AIF-binding proteins [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR679">679</xref>]. Thus, cytosolic AIF reportedly promotes the translocation of MIF into the nucleus, where MIF precipitates parthanatos by catalyzing DNA cleavage. Accordingly, MIF depletion or specific mutations in its nuclease domain confer protection against parthanatos in vitro and in vivo (in an experimental model of focal cerebral ischemia) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR679">679</xref>]. Another protein involved in parthanatos is hexokinase 1 (HK1), whose binding to poly(ADP-ribose) polymers inhibits glycolysis to cause a bioenergetic collapse that precipitates RCD [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR680">680</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR681">681</xref>]. Recently, a non-canonical, AIF-independent instance of parthanatos, presumably centered on the impairment of energetic metabolism, has been proposed to contribute to the demise of retinal epithelial cells and consequent retinal degeneration [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR682">682</xref>]. Interestingly, some authors suggest a certain degree of interconnectivity between the parthanatotic and the necroptotic machineries. Thus, upon induction of necroptosis by TRAIL or β lapachone (an ortho naphthoquinone with antineoplastic activity) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR683">683</xref>], activated RIPK1 and RIPK3 appear to stimulate the enzymatic activity of PARP1 and hence promote ATP depletion and/or AIF release [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR684">684</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR685">685</xref>]. This interpretation may not hold true in all experimental settings [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR686">686</xref>].</p><p id="Par83">Parthanatos reportedly contributes to various pathological conditions, including some cardiovascular and renal disorders, diabetes, cerebral ischemia, and neurodegeneration [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR534">534</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR656">656</xref>
<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR687">687</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR690">690</xref>]. Accordingly, PARP1 inhibition by pharmacological or genetic interventions mediates robust cytoprotective effects in multiple animal models of disease [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR1">1</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR669">669</xref>]. However, further experiments are required to clarify the actual role of parthanatos in the etiology of these (and possible other) pathologies and the true therapeutic benefits of parthanatos-inhibiting agents.</p><p id="Par84">The NCCD proposes to define parthanatos as a form of RCD initiated by PARP1 hyperactivation and precipitated by the consequent bioenergetic catastrophe coupled to AIF-dependent and MIF-dependent DNA degradation (Box <xref ref-type="sec" rid="FPar1">1</xref>).</p></sec><sec id="Sec9"><title>Entotic cell death</title><p id="Par85">Entosis is a form of cell cannibalism that occurs in healthy and malignant mammalian tissues, involving the engulfment of viable cells by non-phagocytic cells of the same (homotypic) or a different (heterotypic) type [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR691">691</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR692">692</xref>]. Often (but not always), internalization is followed by the demise of internalized cells (which are commonly referred to as “entotic cells”) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR691">691</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR693">693</xref>].</p><p id="Par86">Entosis is mainly triggered by the detachment of epithelial cells from the extracellular matrix and consequent loss of integrin signaling [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR263">263</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR694">694</xref>], although alternative mechanisms have been reported. These include: (1) the deregulated expression of myosins during the formation of cell-to-cell contacts [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR695">695</xref>]; and (2) differences in the mechanical properties [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR696">696</xref>] or responses to metabolic stress [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR697">697</xref>] of cancer cells competing for proliferation. Moreover, a recent study suggests the existence of a specific form of entosis occurring in cancer cells during mitosis (entotic mitosis), which is driven by aberrant mitotic rounding (and thus reduced adhesion) in conditions of cell division cycle 42 (CDC42) depletion or upon exposure to antimitotic agents [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR698">698</xref>].</p><p id="Par87">The current model proposes that the internalization of entotic cells occurs through cell invasion rather than by phagocytosis [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR691">691</xref>]. Accordingly, the uptake of entotic cells is an integrin-independent process promoted by the formation of junctions between engulfing and entotic cells that involve the adhesion proteins cadherin 1 (CDH1; also known as E-cadherin) and catenin alpha 1 (CTNNA1) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR694">694</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR699">699</xref>]. Actomyosin chains accumulate at the cortex of internalizing cells (at the pole opposite to the cell-to-cell contact site), via a mechanism that depends on the localized activity of ras homolog family member A (RHOA), Rho associated coiled-coil containing protein kinase 1 (ROCK1), ROCK2, and diaphanous related formin 1 (DIAPH1), and results in a contraction that promotes engulfment [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR695">695</xref>
<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR699">699</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR701">701</xref>]. Actin drives entosis by promoting pro-invasive (non-apoptotic) cortical plasma membrane blebbing upon activation of a signaling pathway that involves myocardin-related transcription factor (MRTF) and serum response factor (SRF) culminating with ezrin (EZR) upregulation [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR702">702</xref>]. The regulation of microtubule dynamics by AURKA has also been attributed a role in cell invasion [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR703">703</xref>], but the relevance of AURKA signaling for entosis awaits experimental confirmation. In line with the actomyosin-dependent cell-in-cell invasion model, the administration of exogenous CDH1 promotes entosis among CDH1-deficient breast cancer cells, whereas forced overexpression of RHOA or ROCK1 plus ROCK2 enables the internalization of entotic cells by epithelial CDH1-expressing cells [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR701">701</xref>]. In addition, hyperactivation of contractile myosin induces entotic cell-in-cell invasion via a mechanism involving the activation of RHOA, ROCK1, and ROCK2 [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR695">695</xref>]. Intriguingly, competition in the tumor system can occur via an entotic process whose outcome is dictated by the activation of KRAS proto-oncogene, GTPase (KRAS), and Rac family small GTPase 1 (RAC1) signaling, which confers an advantage to engulfing cells by favoring myosin downregulation [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR696">696</xref>]. In this context, it has recently been demonstrated that, in conditions of glucose withdrawal, cells displaying high 5′ AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) activity succumb to entosis, underscoring a possible function of this process for nutrient recovery by cells with comparatively lower AMPK activity (which a priori are metabolically fitter) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR697">697</xref>].</p><p id="Par88">Once engulfed, entotic cells are often eliminated by a RCD subroutine that occurs independently of BCL2 proteins and caspases [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR694">694</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR704">704</xref>], but relies (at least in part) on a specific autophagy-related process commonly known as LC3-associated phagocytosis (LAP) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR509">509</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR705">705</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR706">706</xref>]. In this context, some (but not all) components of the macroautophagy apparatus, including microtubule associated protein 1 light chain 3 beta (MAP1LC3B; best known as LC3), autophagy related 5 (ATG5), ATG7, and phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase catalytic subunit type 3 (PIK3C3; best known as VPS34) are recruited to the cytosolic side of entotic cell-containing vesicles and promote their fusion with lysosomes (in the absence of bona fide autophagosome formation) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR704">704</xref>]. Eventually, the lysosomal degradation of internalized entotic cells generates nutrients that are recovered by engulfing cells, via a mechanism that reportedly involves phosphoinositide kinase, FYVE-type zinc finger containing (PIKFYVE) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR704">704</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR707">707</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR708">708</xref>].</p><p id="Par89">Entotic cell death has been documented in several human neoplasms, presumably operating as an oncosuppressor mechanism [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR694">694</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR695">695</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR701">701</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR709">709</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR710">710</xref>]. Thus, abrogation of entosis by a chemical ROCK inhibitor reportedly favors the anchorage-independent growth of malignant cells [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR694">694</xref>]. However, entotic invasion has also been suggested to favor aneuploidization and polyploidization (which promote tumor progression) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR711">711</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR713">713</xref>] through a mechanism involving cytokinesis failure of engulfing cells [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR714">714</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR715">715</xref>]. A potential role for entosis in development and tissue homeostasis has recently been proposed. Thus, in the course of mammalian embryo implantation, trophoblast cells reportedly eliminate uterine luminal epithelial cells upon entosis [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR716">716</xref>]. Moreover, the spermatozoa of hibernating Chinese soft-shelled turtle appear to be degraded within Sertoli cell by entotic cell death [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR717">717</xref>]. Further experiments are required to elucidate the actual role of entosis in the pathophysiology of mammalian organisms. Importantly, entosis does not always lead to the death of invading cells within the lysosome. Thus, at least in some circumstances, entotic cells remain viable and even proliferate inside host cells or upon escape [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR716">716</xref>].</p><p id="Par90">On the basis of this consideration, we propose to define entotic cell death as a form of RCD that originates from actomyosin-dependent cell-in-cell internalization and is executed by lysosomes (Box <xref ref-type="sec" rid="FPar1">1</xref>). In the absence of precise experimental determination of terminal cell fate, we recommend to use the term entosis to refer to the internalization process only.</p></sec><sec id="Sec10"><title>NETotic cell death</title><p id="Par91">The term “NETotic cell death” refers to a rather controversial type of RCD initially characterized in neutrophils for being associated with the extrusion of a meshwork of chromatin-containing and histone-containing fibers bound to granular and cytoplasmic proteins known as neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs), a process commonly referred to as NETosis [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR718">718</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR719">719</xref>]. NETs, which are produced in response to various microbial and sterile activators or upon stimulation of specific receptors including (but not limited to) TLRs, de facto constitute a stable extracellular platform for trapping and degrading microbes [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR718">718</xref>
<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR720">720</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR723">723</xref>]. Several reports demonstrate that a considerable fraction of the nucleic acids contained in NETs is of mitochondrial, rather than nuclear, origin [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR724">724</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR728">728</xref>]. Besides having antimicrobial effects, NETs reportedly contribute to the etiology of some human pathologies, including diabetes and cancer [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR729">729</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR731">731</xref>]. Of note, NET-like structures can be released by cells other than neutrophils, including mast cells [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR732">732</xref>], eosinophils [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR733">733</xref>], and basophils [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR734">734</xref>]. Importantly, NET extrusion per se does not necessarily result in cellular lysis [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR722">722</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR724">724</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR735">735</xref>].</p><p id="Par92">Although the precise molecular mechanisms underlying NET generation are not fully elucidated, both NETotic cell death and NET extrusion in the absence of RCD appears to rely on the activity of NADPH oxidases [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR724">724</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR736">736</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR737">737</xref>]. NETotic cell death has been suggested to result from a signaling pathway that involves Raf-1 proto-oncogene, serine/threonine kinase (RAF1), mitogen-activated protein kinase kinases (MAP2Ks), and ERK2, culminating with NADPH oxidase activation and consequent ROS generation [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR736">736</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR738">738</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR739">739</xref>]. According to this model, intracellular ROS would drive NETotic cell death (1) by triggering the release of elastase, neutrophil expressed (ELANE), and myeloperoxidase (MPO) from neutrophil granules to the cytosol, followed by their translocation to the nucleus, and (2) by promoting the MPO-dependent proteolytic activity of ELANE [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR740">740</xref>]. Once activated, the cytosolic pool of ELANE would catalyze the proteolysis of F-actin, followed by an impairment of cytoskeleton dynamics [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR741">741</xref>]. Alongside, the nuclear pool of ELANE would promote the degradation of histones (and possibly of the nuclear envelope) and, in conjunction with MPO, chromatin decondensation [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR737">737</xref>
<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR740">740</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR742">742</xref>]. This would culminate with the extrusion of chromatin fibers intermixed with cytoplasmic and nuclear components, ultimately leading to plasma membrane rupture and RCD [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR736">736</xref>]. That said, recent findings indicate that ROS drive NET extrusion by a mechanism that requires an intact cytoskeleton [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR743">743</xref>]. Moreover, ELANE is dispensable for NET formation in the course of deep vein thrombosis (in mice) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR744">744</xref>]. Peptidyl arginine deiminase 4 (PADI4; also known as PAD4) has also been proposed to participate in chromatin dispersion [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR745">745</xref>], but its actual involvement remains a matter of debate and appears to depend on the initiating stimulus [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR746">746</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR747">747</xref>]. Finally, NETotic cell death has been proposed to depend (at least in part) on components of the necroptotic apparatus, based on the fact that the administration of chemical RIPK1 or MLKL inhibitors (i.e., Nec-1 or NSA, respectively) as well as the <italic>Ripk3</italic><sup><italic>−/−</italic></sup> genotype appeared to inhibit NET extrusion and neutrophil lysis [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR748">748</xref>]. However, <italic>Ripk3</italic><sup><italic>−/−</italic></sup> neutrophils as well as neutrophils exposed to NSA were fully proficient in NET formation in another study [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR749">749</xref>]. These apparently contradicting findings call for additional studies to address the precise contribution of necroptosis to NET extrusion and NETotic cell death.</p><p id="Par93">We propose to define NETotic cell death as a ROS-dependent modality of RCD restricted to cells of hematopoietic derivation and associated with NET extrusion (Box <xref ref-type="sec" rid="FPar1">1</xref>). That said, it is clear that NET can be formed and extruded by fully viable neutrophils, eosinophils, and basophils. Thus, the NCCD recommends to avoid the use of the term NETosis when no experimental evidence in support of cell death (vs, NET extrusion only) is available. Moreover, we discourage the use of alternative terms proposed to describe this process, including ETosis.</p></sec><sec id="Sec11"><title>Lysosome-dependent cell death</title><p id="Par94">Lysosome-dependent cell death is a subroutine of RCD initiated by perturbations of intracellular homeostasis and demarcated by the permeabilization of lysosomal membranes. Lysosome-dependent cell death is relevant for several pathophysiological conditions, including inflammation, tissue remodeling (e.g., mammary gland involution after lactation), aging, neurodegeneration, cardiovascular disorders, and intracellular pathogen response [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR750">750</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR752">752</xref>]. Moreover, a type of RCD that is highly reminiscent of lysosome-dependent cell death, which has been dubbed “germ cell death”, appears to play a critical role in the physiological elimination of a fraction of emerging male germ cells (at least in <italic>D. melanogaster</italic>) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR753">753</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR756">756</xref>].</p><p id="Par95">At a biochemical level, lysosome-dependent cell death proceeds upon lysosomal membrane permeabilization (LMP), resulting in the release of lysosomal contents, including proteolytic enzymes of the cathepsin family, to the cytoplasm [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR750">750</xref>]. The molecular mechanisms operating upstream of LMP are not fully elucidated. In some circumstances, LMP appears to occur downstream of MOMP as a result of apoptotic signaling, de facto constituting an epiphenomenon of intrinsic apoptosis [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR757">757</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR759">759</xref>]. In other experimental settings, however, lysosomes are permeabilized before mitochondria [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR752">752</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR760">760</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR761">761</xref>], via a mechanism that optionally involves BAX recruitment to the lysosomal membrane followed by the activation of its pore-forming activity [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR762">762</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR765">765</xref>]. More commonly, ROS play a prominent causal role in LMP, not only as the H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>-driven luminal production of hydroxyl radicals by Fenton reactions destabilizes the lysosomal membrane upon lipid peroxidation [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR766">766</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR767">767</xref>], but also as ROS reportedly favor the activation of lysosomal Ca<sup>2+</sup> channels [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR768">768</xref>]. Primary LMP has been documented in vitro in cells responding to specific pro-apoptotic stimuli, including the administration of lysosomotropic agents such as <italic>L</italic>-leucyl-<italic>L</italic>-leucine methyl ester, ciprofloxacin, and hydroxychloroquine, TRAIL signaling, and viral infection [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR760">760</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR761">761</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR765">765</xref>
<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR769">769</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR772">772</xref>], as well in an animal model of Parkinson's disease [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR764">764</xref>]. The p53 effector DNA damage regulated autophagy modulator 1 (DRAM1) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR773">773</xref>] provides a major contribution to lysosome-dependent cell death in HIV1-infected T cells by linking LMP to MOMP [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR770">770</xref>]. Additional LMP triggers include lysosomotropic agents (e.g., sphingosine), calpains, and ROS [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR751">751</xref>]. Moreover, STAT3 reportedly promotes lysosome-dependent cell death during the involution of mammary gland post-lactation as it upregulates the expression of cathepsin B (CTSB) and CTSL, while downregulating their endogenous inhibitor serine (or cysteine) peptidase inhibitor, clade A, member 3G (SERPINA3G; best known as SPI2A) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR774">774</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR775">775</xref>].</p><p id="Par96">Cytosolic cathepsins usually precipitate RCD by catalyzing the proteolytic activation or inactivation of several substrates, including BID, BAX, anti-apoptotic BCL2 family members, and XIAP [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR776">776</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR778">778</xref>], hence engaging a feed-forward amplification circuitry of the lethal cascade involving MOMP and caspases. Moreover, primary lysosomal dysfunction may negatively affect the mitochondrial network as a consequence of impaired mitophagic responses (which normally target damaged or dysfunctional mitochondria to lysosomes for degradation) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR779">779</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR780">780</xref>]. In aged neutrophils, LMP also allows for the release of proteinase 3 (PRTN3) from cytotoxic granules, where it promotes RCD by catalyzing the proteolytic activation of CASP3 [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR781">781</xref>]. Of note, lysosome-dependent cell death does not necessarily involve MOMP and caspases, and does not necessarily manifest with an apoptotic morphotype [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR782">782</xref>]. Moreover, CTSL appears to play a key role in the regulation of autophagic adaptation vs. RCD in cells responding to the LMP inducer resveratrol [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR783">783</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR784">784</xref>]. These observations suggest that LMP and lysosome-dependent cell death are intimately interconnected with adaptative responses to stress and other RCD subroutines.</p><p id="Par97">Lysosome-dependent cell death can be retarded in vitro and in vivo by inhibiting LMP or blocking cathepsin activity via pharmacological or genetic means [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR750">750</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR752">752</xref>]. Commonly employed cathepsin-targeting molecules include endogenous protease inhibitors (cystatins and serpins), as well as various pharmacological agents specific for cysteine cathepsins (e.g., E64D and Ca-074-Me) or aspartyl cathepsins (e.g., pepstatin A) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR785">785</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR787">787</xref>]. Moreover, under physiological conditions, lysosomal membranes can be stabilized by altering lysosomal cholesterol content [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR788">788</xref>] or by boosting endogenous activity of heat shock protein family A (Hsp70) member 1A (HSPA1A; best known as HSP70) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR789">789</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR790">790</xref>]. In line with this notion, the administration of recombinant HSP70 or the HSP70-inducing agent arimiclomol reverts lysosomal abnormalities in cellula as well as in murine models of various lysosomal storage disorders [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR789">789</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR791">791</xref>]. Of relevance for cancer therapy, cancer cells may present an increased sensitivity to lysosomotropic agents and are generally vulnerable to LMP, which supports the clinical development of LCD-inducing agents [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR752">752</xref>
<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR792">792</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR795">795</xref>].</p><p id="Par98">We propose to define lysosome-dependent cell death as a form of RCD demarcated by primary LMP and precipitated by cathepsins, with optional involvement of MOMP and executioner caspases (Box <xref ref-type="sec" rid="FPar1">1</xref>).</p></sec><sec id="Sec12"><title>Autophagy-dependent cell death</title><p id="Par99">Autophagy-dependent cell death is a type of RCD that relies on the autophagic machinery or components thereof [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR509">509</xref>
<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR796">796</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR798">798</xref>]. Proficient autophagic responses (which are under tight transcriptional and post-translational regulation) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR509">509</xref>
<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR799">799</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR805">805</xref>] most often operate at the hub of adaptation to stress, hence mediating cytoprotective (rather than cytotoxic) effects [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR806">806</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR811">811</xref>]. Thus, blocking autophagy with pharmacological or genetic interventions generally accelerates (rather than delays) the demise of cells responding to stress, and permanent or transient endogenous defects in autophagy have been associated with embryonic lethality, developmental defects, and multiple pathological disorders, including (but not limited to) neurodegeneration, cancer, and cardiovascular disorders [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR812">812</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR817">817</xref>]. However, in a number of developmental and pathophysiological settings, the molecular machinery for autophagy etiologically contributes to cellular demise [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR796">796</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR798">798</xref>
<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR818">818</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR820">820</xref>]. Thus, the term autophagy-dependent cell death does not refer to settings in which the autophagic apparatus (or components thereof) is activated alongside (rather than precipitates) RCD [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR821">821</xref>] or it favors the engagement of other RCD modalities, such as (1) ferroptosis, which is promoted by the autophagic degradation of ferritin (ferritinophagy) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR573">573</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR574">574</xref>]; (2) FAS-driven extrinsic apoptosis, which is enhanced by the autophagic degradation of protein tyrosine phosphatase, non-receptor type 13 (PTPN13; best known as FAP1) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR822">822</xref>], and (3) necroptosis, which is favored by a necrosome-scaffolding function of the autophagy apparatus [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR823">823</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR825">825</xref>], as well as by the autophagic degradation of c-IAP1 and c-IAP2 [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR826">826</xref>].</p><p id="Par100">The genetics and pathophysiological significance of autophagy-dependent cell death is now well established [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR818">818</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR820">820</xref>]. Thus, whereas the genetic inactivation of caspases in the midgut of developing <italic>D. melanogaster</italic> has no consequences, mutations or deletions in essential autophagy-related (<italic>Atg</italic>) genes suppress midgut tissue degradation [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR827">827</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR829">829</xref>]. Along similar lines, the complete removal of larval salivary glands from <italic>D. melanogaster</italic> larvae undergoing metamorphosis requires the apoptotic as well as the autophagic machinery [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR830">830</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR832">832</xref>]. In both these developmental scenarios, autophagy-dependent cell death is preceded by growth arrest and is controlled by ecdysone, a steroid hormone that is critically required in <italic>Drosophila</italic> to undergo the larva-to-pupa transition and subsequent metamorphosis into an adult fly [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR830">830</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR833">833</xref>]. The autophagic machinery also precipitates germ cell and ventral cord neuron RCD during <italic>C. elegans</italic> development [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR834">834</xref>], and perhaps contributes to embryonic development in mammals, as suggested by the fact that <italic>Atg5</italic> ablation in apoptosis-deficient (i.e., <italic>Bax</italic><sup><italic>−/−</italic></sup><italic>Bak</italic><sup><italic>−/−</italic></sup>) mice further delays interdigital web clearance, aggravates cerebral abnormalities (at least in the C57BL/6 background), impairs negative selection of autoreactive thymocytes, and increases the resistance of some cell types to multiple stressors [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR835">835</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR836">836</xref>].</p><p id="Par101">Of note, the molecular machinery of autophagy-dependent cell death and adaptative autophagy exhibit some differences (at least in <italic>D. melanogaster</italic>) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR837">837</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR838">838</xref>]. For example, the autophagy-dependent degradation of the midgut tissue proceeds independently of <italic>Atg7</italic>, <italic>Atg3,</italic> and several other <italic>Atg</italic> genes that are required for starvation-induced autophagy in the fat body, but relies on ubiquitin activating enzyme 1 (Uba1) [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR837">837</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR838">838</xref>].
